1.22.text: I'm the curator of Renaissance Europe

10.56.text: I'm here with a very small but special selection of jewels

14.64.text:
with miniature portraits of Elizabeth the first
as Queen of England

19.20.text: when we think of Elizabeth we tend to think of the huge emblematic

22.72.text: political portraits but these objects although they are small

27.64.text: still carry a considerable political punch.

31.12.text: So I thought I'd start with a silver medal

34.80.text: which is perhaps the most complex of the lot

38.34.text:
On the front is a three quarter
elaborate portrait of Elizabeth as Queen

43.46.text: and she's wearing a lace ruff, a tight bodice

47.12.text: and fantastic jewels over her breast

49.76.text: showing, indeed, how a jewel like this was

51.90.text: intended to be worn and huge silk sleeves.

55.38.text:
She's wearing the open crown, the Tudor crown 
on her head

58.42.text: and the crown breaks into the Latin legend or inscription

62.22.text: which goes all the way around and says

64.18.text: 'No circle in the world is richer'

67.28.text: and the impression given there is that England

68.92.text: is not only a stable and secure monarchy

71.19.text: but it is also very rich and has imperial ambitions

76.76.text: On the other side of the medal

78.90.text: there is a message showing how Elizabeth identifies

83.00.text: and how she is their political salvation

90.44.text: and it shows a single island in the middle

92.42.text: of a stormy sea with ships on it

94.80.text: and the island has one single tree growing on it

98.37.text: a bay tree, which is thought to be impervious to lightning

102.12.text: and that's exactly what's happening out of the stormy sky

105.36.text: a bolt of lightning is hitting the tree

107.34.text: and the tree is surviving and not bursting into flames

110.58.text: and underneath the tree is a message

115.44.text: You're supposed to think of this tree as Elizabeth herself

118.54.text: impervious to danger, the great survivor

121.14.text: of political troubles, of conspiracies inside her country

124.86.text: and a foreign invasion culminating in the Spanish Armada of 1588

128.96.text: and just to make that message clear

130.62.text: on either sides of the bay tree is

136.62.text: and so this medal is known as a danger averted medal,

139.16.text: it's designed by Nicholas Hilliard who was the great court artist

142.23.text: at the court of Queen Elizabeth

143.82.text: a medalist and a painter and miniaturist

146.67.text: and designed to be worn just to show

149.74.text: our debt to the Queen and the way she identifies herself

152.42.text: with the survival and the safety of her people.

155.24.text:
The second medal is really rather
different, this is gold,

159.16.text: it's also designed by Nicholas Hilliard, the great miniaturist and medalist,

164.22.text:
and judging by the style of her dress it's probably
from around 1570 to 80

169.66.text: and here, the exquisitely chased gold portrait,

173.24.text: has been cut out to form a silhouette

176.54.text: and every detail of the Queen's dress is lovingly picked out and chased

180.78.text:
and worked in the gold to give different
subtle differences of texture.

184.68.text: So you see her extraordinarily large velvet sleeves

189.90.text:
the way her corset pushes her breasts up 
'neath her lawn chemise

193.82.text: the wonderful ruffles of her stiff lace collar

197.68.text: and the beautiful braiding of her hair

200.84.text: also the smoothness and sharp profiling of her face.

205.94.text: Around her is a beautiful enameled gold frame

210.06.text: with entwined roses, white and red.

213.20.text: The Roses of York and Lancaster,

215.28.text: the Tudor roses and those are symbolic of the unity

219.16.text:
that her grandfather Henry the seventh 
brought to England

221.36.text: with the Tudor dynasty, after a century of Civil War.

226.22.text:
When you turn it over, against the profile of the Queen
 on the back

231.24.text: is the open crown of the Tudors and beneath that the monogram of the Queen

235.76.text: which spells out every letter in her name

238.90.text:
but the most beautiful detail of all is the
Phoenix

241.96.text: fluttering sensuously out of the flames.

245.02.text: The Phoenix was a legendary female creature

248.98.text: that had the capacity to regenerate itself

251.98.text: it would periodically burst into flames

254.68.text: and then regenerate itself out of its own ashes

257.30.text: but the Phoenix was also associated with

260.31.text: chastity and that was a real problem

263.44.text: because Elizabeth apart from being a female ruler

266.06.text: which was considered a great disadvantage at the time

268.40.text: was also unmarried and didn't have a natural successor.

272.70.text: But she made a great strength out of her virginity

276.50.text: in fact she claims she was in some way

280.38.text: and that reigning with their loves as she

283.23.text: called it was more precious to her than the most precious jewel.

286.94.text: We then have three really interesting jewels,

291.40.text:
fashion accessories made out of 
miniature portraits of the Queen.

295.90.text: These are engraved into onyx, which is a stone

298.65.text:
which has many different horizontal
layers within it

301.18.text: ranging from whites on the uppermost layer

303.38.text: to brown black in the lower most layer

305.63.text: it's almost as if you were bringing out the portrait of the Queen

309.36.text: that's somehow hidden within the stone.

311.30.text:
So there's something rather miraculous going on 
with these miniature portraits.

315.62.text: This one, the smallest one, has been fashioned

318.38.text: into a ring, a very, very beautiful gold ring of the late 16th century

323.48.text: and so it's an obviously intended to be worn at court or by a courtier

327.54.text: as this is something that has been given by the Queen as a token of favour.

331.70.text: We know from John Evelyn's diary in 1654

335.44.text: that he met one of Elizabeth the first's court musicians

340.38.text: and that Jerome Lanier was then wearing a ring just like this one

343.76.text: still remembering and celebrating Elizabeth 50 years after her death.

348.32.text: And I think that gives you an idea of the power of these images

352.02.text: however small they may seem to us.

354.46.text: So what we can see at work here is a queen

358.80.text: who's very aware of the importance of manipulating her own image

363.44.text: as a female ruler in a man's world.

366.16.text: Like Shakespeare the great playwright of her age

368.72.text:
she knew that 'all the world's a
stage'

371.22.text: in fact she actually said that she was very well aware

373.96.text: that rulers particularly were continually performing and in the eyes of their public.

378.62.text: And that's I think one thing that makes these jewels so moving

382.06.text: they are power tools but they're also very intimate

386.60.text: and they're intended to build a personal

388.98.text: relationship between you and the Queen.

391.64.text: If you'd like to come and see these jewels for yourself
